chief_complaint.definition: A heart-related assessment done before surgery to make sure your heart is healthy enough to safely undergo the procedure.
A weight-loss surgery that changes how your stomach and small intestine handle food, helping you eat less and absorb fewer calories.
A series of medical tests and evaluations completed before surgery to ensure you are safe and ready for the procedure.

history_of_present_illness.definition: A formal approval from a heart doctor confirming that your heart is healthy enough to safely undergo surgery.
A weight-loss operation that reroutes part of your digestive system so you eat less and absorb fewer calories.
Medical tests and check-ups done before surgery to identify any health risks that need to be addressed first.
Any discomfort or pain felt in the chest area. Doctors ask about this before surgery to rule out heart problems.
A feeling of not being able to get enough air. In your case, it is described as mild and is being evaluated to make sure it is not related to a heart condition.
Medications used to relieve pain, commonly known as painkillers.
Long-lasting pain in the knee joints that has persisted over time.
A common joint condition where the protective cartilage that cushions the ends of your bones wears down over time, causing pain and stiffness. In your case, it affects your knees.

A test where you exercise (usually on a treadmill) while your heart is monitored to see how well it handles physical activity. Your only discomfort during this test was knee pain, not heart-related symptoms.
Any disease affecting the heart or blood vessels. Your family has no history of this, which is a favorable finding for your surgical evaluation.

review_of_systems.definition: Relating to the heart and blood vessels. This section reviews any symptoms you may have involving your heart or circulation.
Discomfort or pain in the chest area. You reported this occurs very rarely.
Difficulty breathing or feeling winded during physical activity. In your case, this is described as mild.
Relating to the lungs and breathing. No significant issues were noted in this area.
Relating to muscles, bones, and joints. This section covers your chronic knee pain.
Pain affecting both knees. 'Bilateral' means both sides of the body are involved.
A degenerative joint condition where cartilage breaks down, leading to pain and stiffness. This is the known cause of your knee pain.
A test that monitors your heart while you exercise to check for heart problems. Your knee pain was the only discomfort experienced during this test.
General body symptoms such as fever, fatigue, or weight changes. No additional symptoms were reported in this category.

physical_exam.definition: Body Mass Index — a number calculated from your height and weight that helps determine if your weight is in a healthy range. Your BMI of approximately 33.1 places you in the Class I obesity category.
A classification for a BMI between 30 and 34.9, indicating a level of excess body weight that can increase health risks. This is one reason gastric bypass surgery has been recommended for you.
An ultrasound of the heart that uses sound waves to create images showing the heart's structure and how well it pumps blood. Your results were normal.
A test where you walk on a treadmill or pedal a bike while your heart rhythm, blood pressure, and breathing are monitored. It checks how your heart responds to physical effort.
The French term for an exercise stress test — a test that evaluates your heart's function during physical activity.
A wear-and-tear joint condition causing pain and stiffness. Your knee pain during the stress test was attributed to this known condition, not to a heart problem.

assessment.definition: A heart assessment performed before surgery to confirm that your heart is healthy enough for the planned operation.
A surgical weight-loss procedure that modifies your digestive system to help you lose weight.
A medical condition involving excess body fat that can increase the risk of health problems. Your BMI of approximately 33.1 qualifies as Class I obesity.
Body Mass Index — a measure of body fat based on your height and weight. A BMI of 33.1 falls in the obesity range.
An ultrasound imaging test of the heart. Your results showed normal heart structure and function.
A test that monitors how your heart performs during physical activity. Your results were normal.
Diseases that affect the heart or blood vessels, such as heart attacks or heart failure. No evidence of this was found in your evaluation.
A heart-related reason that would make a surgery unsafe. None was found in your case, meaning your heart is considered safe for the planned surgery.
A degenerative joint disease causing pain and stiffness due to breakdown of cartilage. Yours affects the knees and is noted as stable.

plan.definition: Official approval from the cardiologist that your heart is healthy enough for surgery. You have been granted this clearance.
A heart condition that would make surgery too risky. None was identified in your evaluation.
The weight-loss surgery you are planning to have, which modifies your digestive system to help you lose weight.
Pain-relieving medications, also known as painkillers. You reported past use of these.
A future appointment with a heart doctor to check on your heart health. In your case, none is needed unless new heart symptoms develop.
Signs or sensations that may indicate a heart problem, such as chest pain, palpitations, or severe shortness of breath. You should seek medical attention if any arise.
Additional medical tests and evaluations that need to be completed before your surgery can be scheduled.
